ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned the fundamentals of the Russian language. My speaking, reading, and writing skills drastically improved over the course of the semester.

I learned how to read the Cyrillic alphabet, and the nominative, dative, genitive, accusative, and prepositional case of many nouns and adjectives. I also memorized many verbs and learned how to conjugate those verbs in the perfective and imperfective.
I learned how to speak, read, and understand Russian.
I learned basic conversational skills in Russian, Five Russian tenses, and Russian vocabulary.
I developed a basic skill set for speaking and writing in the russian language.

RUSS 110 covered about four out of six of the Russian grammatical cases, focusing mostly on singular forms. Also, a ton of basic verbs -- a ton, plus the past, present, and future tenses. The beginning of the course focused on getting used to the Cyrillic alphabet and basic vocabulary, so your ability to speak didn't really "explode" until much later in the course. In all, I learned basic conversational skills (talking about my family, school, likes/dislikes, where I live, etc.) as with any intro language course.
A better command of the Russian language and a deeper understanding of the Slavic culture.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The greatest strength of this course was the professor. Professor Titus is a phenomenal instructor.

Strengths: Many resources available for help or guidance, textbook/video based, very busy-work homework.

Weaknesses: Crunch weeks in quiz/test weeks aka inconsistent workload, fast pace.

Having daily class and homework was very effective for my learning. I felt like that helped me understand the grammatical concepts better, especially in reading and writing. It would be beneficial to have more one-on-one speaking and/or listening practice.

The class engagement and opportunities to participate were always high, making it easy to learn and practice Russian. I also felt that the homework everyday helped in reinforcing what was learned in class. I think one weakness was that there was not enough experience with actual Russian media. I think more examples of modern Russian media could help in improving exposure to conversational Russian.
The canvas site was very user friendly, and the home work every night was really helpful in reinforcing writing and reading in russian. I cannot think of any weaknesses of this course.

Strengths: There is speaking/writing practice built into class time, where the professor/TA leads the class in conversational/worksheet exercises -- that was very handy while learning Russian. The exams were also designed well: challenging, both oral and written, giving you a chance to really test/show off your knowledge. Weaknesses: But I would have liked more vocabulary reinforcement: I found myself learning material on my own much more than I ever did in class. The everyday homework was good for applying what I learned, but I wish there had been more structure to the actual class, too: less just flipping around the textbook and more note taking and discussions -- maybe group flashcard practice and more identifying exercises (like Alana's slide on colors).
Well structured and in line with the textbook and excercises.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I would recommend this course to any student interested in learning Russian.
I would recommend this course to another student if they are willing to contribute a significant amount of time to the study of Russian language. Otherwise, another language might be better.

Yes! If you are looking for a useful language that isn't Spanish or French, Russian is engaging and fulfilling (once you realize how much you've learned by the end of the semester). It's definitely challenging, but it's rewarding.
yes
I definitely would. I feel like although sometimes the course load could be heavy, it is as manageable and helped me learn what I feel to be an adequately sized portion of a new language.
Yes, I would recommend this course. I would recommend it because you learn a lot about Russian language and Russian culture.
Yes! Julia is an awesome instructor
Yes!! Learning Russian is an extremely humbling experience, but so rewarding!!
Yes! The syllabus was well-structured and course materials engaging.
